elements.content: By adjustment of the arm lengths of two triphenylamine-based ligands, two nearly isostructural metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, the reported nanoporous FIR-29 (FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) and the new microporous FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), are obtained, and all exhibit honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by tris­[(4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl]­amine (H3TCPA) ligands and 4,4′,4′′-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB) ligands, respectively. Although the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (1117 m2 g–1) and pore size (8.5 Å) of FJI-Y9 are much lower than those (BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1 and pore size of 16 Å) of the reported FIR-29 because of the shorter arm lengths of H3NTB, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht. The above results indicate that small pores in MOFs are beneficial to the uptake of some special gases including H2, D2, C2H2, etc.
elements.clean_text: By adjustment of the arm lengths of two triphenylamine-based ligands, two nearly isostructural metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, the reported nanoporous FIR-29 (FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) and the new microporous FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), are obtained, and all exhibit honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by tris[(4-carboxyl)phenylduryl]amine (H3TCPA) ligands and 4,4',4''-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB) ligands, respectively. Although the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (1117 m2 g-1) and pore size (8.5 Å) of FJI-Y9 are much lower than those (BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1 and pore size of 16 Å) of the reported FIR-29 because of the shorter arm lengths of H3NTB, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht. The above results indicate that small pores in MOFs are beneficial to the uptake of some special gases including H2, D2, C2H2, etc.

elements.content:
Presented here are two triphenylamine-based metal−organic frameworks that are nearly isostructural porous but show distinct gas uptake because of their different apertures.

Introduction

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with stably porous frameworks, controllable aperture, and high surface area have been broadly applied in molecule sorption and separation. To obtain MOFs with different pore sizes for sorption, the systematic expansion of ligands is an effective strategy to regulate the pore aperture of MOFs. For example, the expansion of a well-known MOF-74, from the original dioxidoterephthalate link of 1 (I) benzene ring to 2 (II), 3 (III), 4 (IV), 5 (V), 6 (VI), 7 (VII), 9 (IX), and 11 (XI) gives an isoreticular series of IRMOF-74-I to -XI with pore apertures ranging from 14 to 98 Å, in which oligo­(ethylene glycol)-functionalized IRMOF-74-VII and -IX have large enough apertures for natural protein sorption. By employment of the same strategy, an isoreticular series of IRMOF-5- and IRUIO-66-type frameworks with extremely large pore aperture characteristics could also be constructed. Although these expansionary structures always showed high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for N2 sorption, as is known, rarely efforts were focused on the vital importance of proper apertures in isoreticular MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage. Actually, H2, D2, and C2H2 are widely used in clean energy, nuclear chemistry, and organic chemicals, respectively. Therefore, efficient storage of these gases is urgently demanded and extremely challenging. It is reported that, except for the open metallic site, the pore aperture in MOFs is the most important factor in capturing H2, D2, and C2H2. An effective strategy for optimizing H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption is to synthesize MOFs with different pore sizes by controlling the arm lengths of the ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Presented here are two triphenylamine-based metal-organic frameworks that are nearly isostructural porous but show distinct gas uptake because of their different apertures.

Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with stably porous frameworks, controllable aperture, and high surface area have been broadly applied in molecule sorption and separation. To obtain MOFs with different pore sizes for sorption, the systematic expansion of ligands is an effective strategy to regulate the pore aperture of MOFs. For example, the expansion of a well-known MOF-74, from the original dioxidoterephthalate link of 1 (I) benzene ring to 2 (II), 3 (III), 4 (IV), 5 (V), 6 (VI), 7 (VII), 9 (IX), and 11 (XI) gives an isoreticular series of IRMOF-74-I to -XI with pore apertures ranging from 14 to 98 Å, in which oligo(ethylene glycol)-functionalized IRMOF-74-VII and -IX have large enough apertures for natural protein sorption. By employment of the same strategy, an isoreticular series of IRMOF-5- and IRUIO-66-type frameworks with extremely large pore aperture characteristics could also be constructed. Although these expansionary structures always showed high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for N2 sorption, as is known, rarely efforts were focused on the vital importance of proper apertures in isoreticular MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage. Actually, H2, D2, and C2H2 are widely used in clean energy, nuclear chemistry, and organic chemicals, respectively. Therefore, efficient storage of these gases is urgently demanded and extremely challenging. It is reported that, except for the open metallic site, the pore aperture in MOFs is the most important factor in capturing H2, D2, and C2H2. An effective strategy for optimizing H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption is to synthesize MOFs with different pore sizes by controlling the arm lengths of the ligands.

elements.content: In our previous work, we reported a nanoporous MOF (FIR-29, FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) that consisted of Ca-COO chains linked by tris­[(4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl]­amine (H3TCPA; ) ligands and showed large hexagonal channels with an aperture of 16 Å and a high BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1. However, the H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption properties for FIR-29 have not been investigated. Herein, we are inclined to employ another shorter triphenylamine-based ligand, 4,4′,4′′-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB), to replace H3TCPA during the synthesis process, leading to an isoreticular MOF with narrower pore sizes. These two isoreticular MOFs will provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption. On the basis of the above ideas, we successfully synthesized a new Ca-MOF, namely, FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), which exhibits honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by H3NTB ligands, leaving pore sizes of 8.5 Å in the host. Although the BET of 1117 m2 g–1 for the activated FJI-Y9-ht is inferior to that of FIR-29-ht, FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptakes under 77 K and 1 bar, and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all about 50% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht (Table S1). The comparisons of H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption for the activated FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht indicate the advantage of a small pore in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, we reported a nanoporous MOF (FIR-29, FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) that consisted of Ca-COO chains linked by tris[(4-carboxyl)phenylduryl]amine (H3TCPA; ) ligands and showed large hexagonal channels with an aperture of 16 Å and a high BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1. However, the H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption properties for FIR-29 have not been investigated. Herein, we are inclined to employ another shorter triphenylamine-based ligand, 4,4',4''-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB), to replace H3TCPA during the synthesis process, leading to an isoreticular MOF with narrower pore sizes. These two isoreticular MOFs will provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption. On the basis of the above ideas, we successfully synthesized a new Ca-MOF, namely, FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), which exhibits honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by H3NTB ligands, leaving pore sizes of 8.5 Å in the host. Although the BET of 1117 m2 g-1 for the activated FJI-Y9-ht is inferior to that of FIR-29-ht, FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptakes under 77 K and 1 bar, and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all about 50% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht (Table S1). The comparisons of H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption for the activated FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht indicate the advantage of a small pore in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.

elements.clean_text: 1  Chemical Structures of H3TCPA and H3NTB Used for Synthesizing FIR-29 and FJI-Y9, Respectively

elements.content: The solvents and reagents are commercially available and were used directly. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained with a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer. All samples and the reference (Al2O3) were enclosed in a platinum crucible and were heated from 25 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1 under an N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was recorded on a Rigaku Mini 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), and the collecting speed was 5° min–1 and the range of 2θ was 4–50° at room temperature. The simulated PXRD patterns were the corresponding single-crystal structure models calculated by Mercury. Gas adsorption measurement data were collected by the ASAP 2020 system.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

The solvents and reagents are commercially available and were used directly. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained with a NETZSCH STA 449C analyzer. All samples and the reference (Al2O3) were enclosed in a platinum crucible and were heated from 25 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1 under an N2 atmosphere. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was recorded on a Rigaku Mini 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), and the collecting speed was 5° min-1 and the range of 2θ was 4-50° at room temperature. The simulated PXRD patterns were the corresponding single-crystal structure models calculated by Mercury. Gas adsorption measurement data were collected by the ASAP 2020 system.

elements.content: A mixture of Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O (50 mg), H3NTB (50 mg), 5 mL of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of H2O was sealed in an 8 mL vial, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with fresh DMA, yellow crystals of FJI-Y9 were collected in a yield of 67.5%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ca6(NTB)4(DMA)(H2O)3]⋅xguest (FJI-Y9)

A mixture of Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (50 mg), H3NTB (50 mg), 5 mL of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of H2O was sealed in an 8 mL vial, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with fresh DMA, yellow crystals of FJI-Y9 were collected in a yield of 67.5%.

elements.content: Crystal Data of FJI-Y9: C88H57Ca6N5O28, M r = 1872.86, orthorhombic, space group Pca21, a = 28.5175(3) Å, b = 18.6224(2) Å, c = 23.4007(2) Å, V = 12427.3(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 1.001 g cm–3, F 000 = 3856, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å, T = 100.0(2) K, 2θmax = 146.3°, 24743 reflections collected, 15121 unique (R int = 0.0281), final GOF = 1.050, R 1 = 0.0427, wR 2 = 0.1116, R indices based on 13772 reflections with I > 2σ­(Ι) (refinement on F 2).
elements.clean_text: Crystal Data of FJI-Y9: C88H57Ca6N5O28, M r = 1872.86, orthorhombic, space group Pca21, a = 28.5175(3) Å, b = 18.6224(2) Å, c = 23.4007(2) Å, V = 12427.3(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 1.001 g cm-3, F 000 = 3856, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å, T = 100.0(2) K, 2θmax = 146.3°, 24743 reflections collected, 15121 unique (R int = 0.0281), final GOF = 1.050, R 1 = 0.0427, wR 2 = 0.1116, R indices based on 13772 reflections with I > 2σ(Ι) (refinement on F 2).

elements.content: To explore the adsorption sites of H2, D2, and C2H2 molecules in FJI-Y9 and FIR-29, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were carried out using the in-house multipurpose code RASPA2.0. The framework atoms were kept fixed at their crystallographic positions in the simulation, and Feynman–Hibbs corrections were used in the simulations of H2 and D2. Lennard-Jones (LJ) parameters for the framework atoms were taken from the Dreiding force field and the H2, D2, and C2H2 LJ parameters from the TraPPE force field. Lorentz–Berthelot mixing rules were used for all cross terms, and the LJ interactions beyond 12.8 Å were neglected. Coulomb interactions were calculated using partial charges on the framework atoms. The Ewald sum method was used to compute the electrostatic interactions. A total of 50000 Monte Carlo equilibration cycles were performed plus 50000 production cycles to calculate the ensemble averages. In one cycle, an average of N moves was performed, where N is the number of molecules in the system. Monte Carlo moves used with equal probability were translation, rotation, insertion, deletion, and random reinsertion of an existing molecule at a new position.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

To explore the adsorption sites of H2, D2, and C2H2 molecules in FJI-Y9 and FIR-29, grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations were carried out using the in-house multipurpose code RASPA2.0. The framework atoms were kept fixed at their crystallographic positions in the simulation, and Feynman-Hibbs corrections were used in the simulations of H2 and D2. Lennard-Jones (LJ) parameters for the framework atoms were taken from the Dreiding force field and the H2, D2, and C2H2 LJ parameters from the TraPPE force field. Lorentz-Berthelot mixing rules were used for all cross terms, and the LJ interactions beyond 12.8 Å were neglected. Coulomb interactions were calculated using partial charges on the framework atoms. The Ewald sum method was used to compute the electrostatic interactions. A total of 50000 Monte Carlo equilibration cycles were performed plus 50000 production cycles to calculate the ensemble averages. In one cycle, an average of N moves was performed, where N is the number of molecules in the system. Monte Carlo moves used with equal probability were translation, rotation, insertion, deletion, and random reinsertion of an existing molecule at a new position.

elements.content: Solvent-thermal reaction of Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O and H3NTB in a mixed solvent of DMA and H2O resulted in the formation of FJI-Y9. Single-crystal X-ray analysis confirms that FJI-Y9 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pca21. In the structure of FJI-Y9, each asymmetric unit consists of six independent Ca2+ ions, four NTB3– ligands, one terminal DMA, and three terminal H2O molecules. These six independent Ca2+ ions with 6- or 7-coordinated geometries are bridged by carboxyl groups and terminal solvent molecules (a) to form a metallic hexamer Ca6(COO)12 and further connected by the rest of the carboxyl groups to generate an infinite Ca-COO chain along the c axis. The NTB3– ligands around the Ca-COO chain are tightly packed to show a continuous slipped π···π-stacking interaction with a distance of about 3.523–3.745 Å measured from the distances of two edges between adjacent phenyl rings (b), which will actually improve the stability of the host framework. Each neutral Ca-COO chain is connected to six other chains by the rest of the triphenylamine groups along the ab plane to generate the final 3D rod-packing architecture (c). On the basis of the pore parameters estimated by using the Zeo++ software developed by Haranczyk’s groups, the structure of FJI-Y9 without all of the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules exhibits hexagonal channels with an aperture of 8.5 Å running along the b axis and an accessible pore volume of about 45.4% of the total crystal volume. Although FJI-Y9 has a 3D rod-packing architecture nearly similar to that of the previously reported FIR-29, the pore parameters of FJI-Y9 are all inferior because the triangular tricarboxylic ligand H3NTB possesses much shorter arm lengths than the triangular tricarboxylic ligand H3TCPA. These two nearly isostructural MOFs provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on different gas sorptions, especially for some special gases including H2, D2, and C2H2.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvent-thermal reaction of Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O and H3NTB in a mixed solvent of DMA and H2O resulted in the formation of FJI-Y9. Single-crystal X-ray analysis confirms that FJI-Y9 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pca21. In the structure of FJI-Y9, each asymmetric unit consists of six independent Ca2+ ions, four NTB3- ligands, one terminal DMA, and three terminal H2O molecules. These six independent Ca2+ ions with 6- or 7-coordinated geometries are bridged by carboxyl groups and terminal solvent molecules (a) to form a metallic hexamer Ca6(COO)12 and further connected by the rest of the carboxyl groups to generate an infinite Ca-COO chain along the c axis. The NTB3- ligands around the Ca-COO chain are tightly packed to show a continuous slipped π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interaction with a distance of about 3.523-3.745 Å measured from the distances of two edges between adjacent phenyl rings (b), which will actually improve the stability of the host framework. Each neutral Ca-COO chain is connected to six other chains by the rest of the triphenylamine groups along the ab plane to generate the final 3D rod-packing architecture (c). On the basis of the pore parameters estimated by using the Zeo++ software developed by Haranczyk's groups, the structure of FJI-Y9 without all of the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules exhibits hexagonal channels with an aperture of 8.5 Å running along the b axis and an accessible pore volume of about 45.4% of the total crystal volume. Although FJI-Y9 has a 3D rod-packing architecture nearly similar to that of the previously reported FIR-29, the pore parameters of FJI-Y9 are all inferior because the triangular tricarboxylic ligand H3NTB possesses much shorter arm lengths than the triangular tricarboxylic ligand H3TCPA. These two nearly isostructural MOFs provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on different gas sorptions, especially for some special gases including H2, D2, and C2H2.

elements.content: (a) Ca-COO chain running along the c axis in FJI-Y9. (b) Slipped π···π-stacking interaction of NTB3– fragments in FJI-Y9. (c) 3D framework of FJI-Y9 showing microporous hexagonal channels. (d) 3D framework of the reported FIR-29 showing nanoporous hexagonal channels. Color code: C, gray; H, white; N, blue; O, red; Ca, green.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Ca-COO chain running along the c axis in FJI-Y9. (b) Slipped π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interaction of NTB3- fragments in FJI-Y9. (c) 3D framework of FJI-Y9 showing microporous hexagonal channels. (d) 3D framework of the reported FIR-29 showing nanoporous hexagonal channels. Color code: C, gray; H, white; N, blue; O, red; Ca, green.

elements.content: The purity phase of FJI-Y9 has been verified by PXRD measurements (Figure S1). The TGA curve of FJI-Y9 indicates that the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules can be gradually removed at 415 °C with a weight loss of 32% (Figure S2). To attain complete evacuation for gas sorption, the original FJI-Y9 is soaked in fresh acetonitrile under 80 °C for 2 weeks and then degassed under 150 °C for 12 h to generate the activated sample FJI-Y9-ht.
elements.clean_text: The purity phase of FJI-Y9 has been verified by PXRD measurements (Figure S1). The TGA curve of FJI-Y9 indicates that the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules can be gradually removed at 415 °C with a weight loss of 32% (Figure S2). To attain complete evacuation for gas sorption, the original FJI-Y9 is soaked in fresh acetonitrile under 80 °C for 2 weeks and then degassed under 150 °C for 12 h to generate the activated sample FJI-Y9-ht.

elements.content: In order to examine the structural stability and porosity of FJI-Y9-ht, N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K is performed. The saturated N2 uptake for FJI-Y9-ht is 361 cm3 g–1 () under 1 bar, corresponding to a BET surface area of 1117 m2 g–1, which is much lower than that (2061 m2 g–1) of FIR-29-ht under the same measurement conditions (Figure S3). The pore diameter distribution analysis by using density functional theory methods indicates a narrow pore size of 8.5 Å, which is according to the value estimated from the single-crystal structure and is smaller than the aperture diameter existing in FIR-29-ht (Figure S5). On the basis of the above sorption data, a micropore volume of 0.54 cm3 g–1 in FJI-Y9-ht is close to 0.49 cm3 g–1 estimated from the single-crystal structure and further confirms the structural stability of the host framework after heat activation.
elements.clean_text: In order to examine the structural stability and porosity of FJI-Y9-ht, N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K is performed. The saturated N2 uptake for FJI-Y9-ht is 361 cm3 g-1 () under 1 bar, corresponding to a BET surface area of 1117 m2 g-1, which is much lower than that (2061 m2 g-1) of FIR-29-ht under the same measurement conditions (Figure S3). The pore diameter distribution analysis by using density functional theory methods indicates a narrow pore size of 8.5 Å, which is according to the value estimated from the single-crystal structure and is smaller than the aperture diameter existing in FIR-29-ht (Figure S5). On the basis of the above sorption data, a micropore volume of 0.54 cm3 g-1 in FJI-Y9-ht is close to 0.49 cm3 g-1 estimated from the single-crystal structure and further confirms the structural stability of the host framework after heat activation.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K for FIR-29-ht (blue) and FJI-Y9-ht (red).
elements.clean_text: 2  N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K for FIR-29-ht (blue) and FJI-Y9-ht (red).

elements.content: Although FJI-Y9-ht shows much lower BET surface area than FIR-29-ht, the advantage of a narrow pore size will make it an excellent candidate for D2 and H2 storage because narrow pores can induce a strong affinity for binding D2 and H2. Low-pressure D2 and H2 adsorption isotherms collected for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht are shown in . Under 77 K and 1 bar, D2 and H2 uptake values for FJI-Y9-ht reach up to 221.9 and 202.3 cm3 g–1, respectively (a,b). In contrast, FIR-29-ht shows lower D2 and H2 uptake values of 149.7 and 136.8 cm3 g–1, respectively (c,d). The maximum uptake of H2 for FJI-Y9-ht at 77 K is lower than those of FJI-Y3-ht (232.5 cm3 g–1), Mg2(dobdc) (246.4 cm3 g–1), and MOF-505 (276.6 cm3 g–1) but much better than those of other MOFs, such as the typical PCN-121 (156.8 cm3 g–1), and PCN-17 (105 cm3 g–1). What is more, the fraction of the pore volume filled by liquid H2 (ρH2 = 0.0708 g cm–3) at 1 bar and 77 K for FJI-Y9-ht is 47.2%, which is about 2 times enhancement over that (16.4%) of FIR-29-ht. H2 and D2 adsorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht are also measured at 87 K to determine their isosteric heat (Q st) of H2 and D2 sorption. For FJI-Y9-ht, the Q st values of H2 and D2 adsorption calculated from the virial equation are 6.0 and 6.2 kJ mol–1, respectively, which are all slightly higher than those of FIR-29-ht (Figures S6–S9 and S13). For H2 and D2, a pair of stable isotopes, their size, shape, and thermodynamic properties are identical, which makes D2/H2 separation enormously difficult. MOFs with controllable pore structure are excellent candidates for applications in H2/D2 separation. Moderate ideal adsorbed solution theory D2/H2 selectivities of 1.3 and 1.2 are shown for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht, respectively (Figure S10).

Low-pressure D2 and H2 adsorption isotherms collected for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht are shown in . Under 77 K and 1 bar, D2 and H2 uptake values for FJI-Y9-ht reach up to 221.9 and 202.3 cm3 g-1, respectively (a,b). In contrast, FIR-29-ht shows lower D2 and H2 uptake values of 149.7 and 136.8 cm3 g-1, respectively (c,d). The maximum uptake of H2 for FJI-Y9-ht at 77 K is lower than those of FJI-Y3-ht (232.5 cm3 g-1), Mg2(dobdc) (246.4 cm3 g-1), and MOF-505 (276.6 cm3 g-1) but much better than those of other MOFs, such as the typical PCN-121 (156.8 cm3 g-1), and PCN-17 (105 cm3 g-1). What is more, the fraction of the pore volume filled by liquid H2 (ρH2 = 0.0708 g cm-3) at 1 bar and 77 K for FJI-Y9-ht is 47.2%, which is about 2 times enhancement over that (16.4%) of FIR-29-ht. H2 and D2 adsorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht are also measured at 87 K to determine their isosteric heat (Q st) of H2 and D2 sorption. For FJI-Y9-ht, the Q st values of H2 and D2 adsorption calculated from the virial equation are 6.0 and 6.2 kJ mol-1, respectively, which are all slightly higher than those of FIR-29-ht (Figures S6-S9 and S13). MOFs with controllable pore structure are excellent candidates for applications in H2/D2 separation. Moderate ideal adsorbed solution theory D2/H2 selectivities of 1.3 and 1.2 are shown for FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht, respectively (Figure S10).

elements.content: D2 and H2 sorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht (red) and FIR-29-ht (blue): D2 under 77 K (a); H2 under 77 K (b); D2 under 87 K (c); H2 under 87 K (d).
elements.clean_text: 3  D2 and H2 sorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht (red) and FIR-29-ht (blue): D2 under 77 K (a); H2 under 77 K (b); D2 under 87 K (c); H2 under 87 K (d).

elements.content: Previous studies indicated that a suitable pore in MOFs was crucial for C2H2 storage, which encourages us to investigate the C2H2 sorption of FJI-Y9-ht with a narrow pore. As shown in , FJI-Y9-ht takes up different amounts of C2H2 (168.9 and 119.2 cm3 g–1, according to 156.9 and 110.7 cm3 cm–3) under 273 and 298 K and 1 bar, respectively (Table S1). The maximum uptake of C2H2 for FJI-Y9-ht at 273 K is inferior to those of MOFs (such as 290 cm3 g–1 for FJI-H8 and 290 cm3 g–1 for ZJU-5 ) and equal to that of MFM-130a (144 cm3 g–1) but much better than those of some MOFs including NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3 g–1). In other words, FJI-Y9-ht shows a safe C2H2 storage density of 0.123 g cm–3 under 298 K and 1 bar, according to an imaginary state of C2H2 under 11.7 MPa, which is about 57 times enhancement over the compression limit for the safe storage of C2H2 (0.2 MPa) at room temperature. By contrast, FIR-29-ht adsorbs only about half as much C2H2 uptake as FJI-Y9-ht, and its safe C2H2 storage density is just 0.037 g cm–3 under 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, for C2H2 adsorption, FJI-Y9-ht shows a higher Q st value of 21.0 kJ mol–1 than FIR-29-ht (Figures S11–S13). On the basis of the above data, shrinking arm length of the ligands is an effective strategy to prepare MOFs with narrow pores for C2H2 capture.
elements.clean_text: Previous studies indicated that a suitable pore in MOFs was crucial for C2H2 storage, which encourages us to investigate the C2H2 sorption of FJI-Y9-ht with a narrow pore. As shown in , FJI-Y9-ht takes up different amounts of C2H2 (168.9 and 119.2 cm3 g-1, according to 156.9 and 110.7 cm3 cm-3) under 273 and 298 K and 1 bar, respectively (Table S1). The maximum uptake of C2H2 for FJI-Y9-ht at 273 K is inferior to those of MOFs (such as 290 cm3 g-1 for FJI-H8  and 290 cm3 g-1 for ZJU-5 ) and equal to that of MFM-130a (144 cm3 g-1) but much better than those of some MOFs including NKMOF-1-Ni (61.0 cm3 g-1). In other words, FJI-Y9-ht shows a safe C2H2 storage density of 0.123 g cm-3 under 298 K and 1 bar, according to an imaginary state of C2H2 under 11.7 MPa, which is about 57 times enhancement over the compression limit for the safe storage of C2H2 (0.2 MPa) at room temperature. By contrast, FIR-29-ht adsorbs only about half as much C2H2 uptake as FJI-Y9-ht, and its safe C2H2 storage density is just 0.037 g cm-3 under 298 K and 1 bar. Furthermore, for C2H2 adsorption, FJI-Y9-ht shows a higher Q st value of 21.0 kJ mol-1 than FIR-29-ht (Figures S11-S13). On the basis of the above data, shrinking arm length of the ligands is an effective strategy to prepare MOFs with narrow pores for C2H2 capture.

elements.content: C2H2 sorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht (red) and FIR-29-ht (blue) under 273 K (a) and 298 K (b).
elements.clean_text: 4  C2H2 sorption isotherms for FJI-Y9-ht (red) and FIR-29-ht (blue) under 273 K (a) and 298 K (b).

elements.content: To further understand the different affinities to H2, D2, and C2H2 for both MOFs, slices through the calculated potential fields for these gases at 100 Pa pressure are displayed in . As anticipated, the highest potential values are located around the unsaturated metal centers in both MOFs. However, for all gases, it is clear that the potential values located in small pores in FJI-Y9-ht are much stronger than those potential values located in large pores in FIR-29-ht. Therefore, compared to FIR-29-ht, the higher H2, D2, and C2H2 uptake of FJI-Y9-ht can be mainly attributed to the suitable pore space.
elements.clean_text: To further understand the different affinities to H2, D2, and C2H2 for both MOFs, slices through the calculated potential fields for these gases at 100 Pa pressure are displayed in . As anticipated, the highest potential values are located around the unsaturated metal centers in both MOFs. However, for all gases, it is clear that the potential values located in small pores in FJI-Y9-ht are much stronger than those potential values located in large pores in FIR-29-ht. Therefore, compared to FIR-29-ht, the higher H2, D2, and C2H2 uptake of FJI-Y9-ht can be mainly attributed to the suitable pore space.

elements.content: Slices through the calculated potential fields for H2 in FJI-Y9-ht (a) and FIR-29-ht (d) under 77 K, for D2 in FJI-Y9-ht (b) and FIR-29-ht (e) under 77 K, and for C2H2 in FJI-Y9-ht (c) and FIR-29-ht (f) under 273 K. The slice is viewed along the crystallographic b axis for FJI-Y9-ht and the c axis for FIR-29-ht. Both frameworks are displayed in ball-and-stick plots.

The slice is viewed along the crystallographic b axis for FJI-Y9-ht and the c axis for FIR-29-ht. Both frameworks are displayed in ball-and-stick plots.

elements.content: In summary, by adjusting the arm length of two triphenylamine-based ligands (H3NTB and H3TCPA), we synthesized two nearly isostructural MOFs (FJI-Y9 and FIR-29) with honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels. The consecutive slipped π···π-stacking interactions of the H3NTB and H3TCPA ligands on the surface of hexagonal channels make both MOFs stable for gas sorption. Compared to the reported FIR-29-ht with a BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1 and a pore size of 16 Å, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows an inferior BET surface area (1117 m2 g–1) and a narrow pore size (8.5 Å) but exhibits high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht, indicating the vital importance of proper aperture in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, by adjusting the arm length of two triphenylamine-based ligands (H3NTB and H3TCPA), we synthesized two nearly isostructural MOFs (FJI-Y9 and FIR-29) with honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels. The consecutive slipped π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interactions of the H3NTB and H3TCPA ligands on the surface of hexagonal channels make both MOFs stable for gas sorption. Compared to the reported FIR-29-ht with a BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1 and a pore size of 16 Å, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows an inferior BET surface area (1117 m2 g-1) and a narrow pore size (8.5 Å) but exhibits high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht, indicating the vital importance of proper aperture in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O (50 mg), H3NTB (50 mg), 5 mL of N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of H2O was sealed in an 8 mL vial, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with fresh DMA, yellow crystals of FJI-Y9 were collected in a yield of 67.5%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Ca6(NTB)4(DMA)(H2O)3]⋅xguest (FJI-Y9)

A mixture of Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O (50 mg), H3NTB (50 mg), 5 mL of N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA), and 0.5 mL of H2O was sealed in an 8 mL vial, heated at 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. After washing with fresh DMA, yellow crystals of FJI-Y9 were collected in a yield of 67.5%.

cln_elements.content:
By adjustment of the arm lengths of two triphenylamine-based ligands, two nearly isostructural metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, the reported nanoporous FIR-29 (FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) and the new microporous FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), are obtained, and all exhibit honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by tris­[(4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl]­amine (H3TCPA) ligands and 4,4′,4′′-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB) ligands, respectively. Although the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (1117 m2 g–1) and pore size (8.5 Å) of FJI-Y9 are much lower than those (BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1 and pore size of 16 Å) of the reported FIR-29 because of the shorter arm lengths of H3NTB, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht. The above results indicate that small pores in MOFs are beneficial to the uptake of some special gases including H2, D2, C2H2, etc.

In our previous work, we reported a nanoporous MOF (FIR-29, FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) that consisted of Ca-COO chains linked by tris­[(4-carboxyl)­phenylduryl]­amine (H3TCPA; ) ligands and showed large hexagonal channels with an aperture of 16 Å and a high BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1. However, the H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption properties for FIR-29 have not been investigated. Herein, we are inclined to employ another shorter triphenylamine-based ligand, 4,4′,4′′-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB), to replace H3TCPA during the synthesis process, leading to an isoreticular MOF with narrower pore sizes. These two isoreticular MOFs will provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption. On the basis of the above ideas, we successfully synthesized a new Ca-MOF, namely, FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), which exhibits honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by H3NTB ligands, leaving pore sizes of 8.5 Å in the host. Although the BET of 1117 m2 g–1 for the activated FJI-Y9-ht is inferior to that of FIR-29-ht, FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptakes under 77 K and 1 bar, and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all about 50% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht (Table S1). The comparisons of H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption for the activated FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht indicate the advantage of a small pore in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.

Crystal Data of FJI-Y9: C88H57Ca6N5O28, M r = 1872.86, orthorhombic, space group Pca21, a = 28.5175(3) Å, b = 18.6224(2) Å, c = 23.4007(2) Å, V = 12427.3(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 1.001 g cm–3, F 000 = 3856, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å, T = 100.0(2) K, 2θmax = 146.3°, 24743 reflections collected, 15121 unique (R int = 0.0281), final GOF = 1.050, R 1 = 0.0427, wR 2 = 0.1116, R indices based on 13772 reflections with I > 2σ­(Ι) (refinement on F 2).

The purity phase of FJI-Y9 has been verified by PXRD measurements (Figure S1). The TGA curve of FJI-Y9 indicates that the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules can be gradually removed at 415 °C with a weight loss of 32% (Figure S2). To attain complete evacuation for gas sorption, the original FJI-Y9 is soaked in fresh acetonitrile under 80 °C for 2 weeks and then degassed under 150 °C for 12 h to generate the activated sample FJI-Y9-ht.

In order to examine the structural stability and porosity of FJI-Y9-ht, N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K is performed. The saturated N2 uptake for FJI-Y9-ht is 361 cm3 g–1 () under 1 bar, corresponding to a BET surface area of 1117 m2 g–1, which is much lower than that (2061 m2 g–1) of FIR-29-ht under the same measurement conditions (Figure S3). The pore diameter distribution analysis by using density functional theory methods indicates a narrow pore size of 8.5 Å, which is according to the value estimated from the single-crystal structure and is smaller than the aperture diameter existing in FIR-29-ht (Figure S5). On the basis of the above sorption data, a micropore volume of 0.54 cm3 g–1 in FJI-Y9-ht is close to 0.49 cm3 g–1 estimated from the single-crystal structure and further confirms the structural stability of the host framework after heat activation.

Conclusion

In summary, by adjusting the arm length of two triphenylamine-based ligands (H3NTB and H3TCPA), we synthesized two nearly isostructural MOFs (FJI-Y9 and FIR-29) with honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels. The consecutive slipped π···π-stacking interactions of the H3NTB and H3TCPA ligands on the surface of hexagonal channels make both MOFs stable for gas sorption. Compared to the reported FIR-29-ht with a BET surface area of 2061 m2 g–1 and a pore size of 16 Å, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows an inferior BET surface area (1117 m2 g–1) and a narrow pore size (8.5 Å) but exhibits high H2 (202.3 cm3 g–1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g–1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g–1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht, indicating the vital importance of proper aperture in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.
cln_elements.clean_text:
By adjustment of the arm lengths of two triphenylamine-based ligands, two nearly isostructural metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, the reported nanoporous FIR-29 (FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) and the new microporous FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), are obtained, and all exhibit honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by tris[(4-carboxyl)phenylduryl]amine (H3TCPA) ligands and 4,4',4''-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB) ligands, respectively. Although the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area (1117 m2 g-1) and pore size (8.5 Å) of FJI-Y9 are much lower than those (BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1 and pore size of 16 Å) of the reported FIR-29 because of the shorter arm lengths of H3NTB, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht. The above results indicate that small pores in MOFs are beneficial to the uptake of some special gases including H2, D2, C2H2, etc.

In our previous work, we reported a nanoporous MOF (FIR-29, FIR = Fujian Institute of Research) that consisted of Ca-COO chains linked by tris[(4-carboxyl)phenylduryl]amine (H3TCPA; ) ligands and showed large hexagonal channels with an aperture of 16 Å and a high BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1. However, the H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption properties for FIR-29 have not been investigated. Herein, we are inclined to employ another shorter triphenylamine-based ligand, 4,4',4''-nitrilotribenzoic acid (H3NTB), to replace H3TCPA during the synthesis process, leading to an isoreticular MOF with narrower pore sizes. These two isoreticular MOFs will provide an ideal platform to explore the effect of pore aperture on H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption. On the basis of the above ideas, we successfully synthesized a new Ca-MOF, namely, FJI-Y9 (FJI = Fujian Institute), which exhibits honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels with Ca-COO chains connected by H3NTB ligands, leaving pore sizes of 8.5 Å in the host. Although the BET of 1117 m2 g-1 for the activated FJI-Y9-ht is inferior to that of FIR-29-ht, FJI-Y9-ht shows high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptakes under 77 K and 1 bar, and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all about 50% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht (Table S1). The comparisons of H2, D2, and C2H2 sorption for the activated FJI-Y9-ht and FIR-29-ht indicate the advantage of a small pore in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.

 Crystal Data of FJI-Y9: C88H57Ca6N5O28, M r = 1872.86, orthorhombic, space group Pca21, a = 28.5175(3) Å, b = 18.6224(2) Å, c = 23.4007(2) Å, V = 12427.3(2) Å3, Z = 4, D c = 1.001 g cm-3, F 000 = 3856, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.54184 Å, T = 100.0(2) K, 2θmax = 146.3°, 24743 reflections collected, 15121 unique (R int = 0.0281), final GOF = 1.050, R 1 = 0.0427, wR 2 = 0.1116, R indices based on 13772 reflections with I > 2σ(Ι) (refinement on F 2).

The purity phase of FJI-Y9 has been verified by PXRD measurements (Figure S1). The TGA curve of FJI-Y9 indicates that the dissociative and coordinated solvent molecules can be gradually removed at 415 °C with a weight loss of 32% (Figure S2). To attain complete evacuation for gas sorption, the original FJI-Y9 is soaked in fresh acetonitrile under 80 °C for 2 weeks and then degassed under 150 °C for 12 h to generate the activated sample FJI-Y9-ht.

In order to examine the structural stability and porosity of FJI-Y9-ht, N2 adsorption measurement at 77 K is performed. The saturated N2 uptake for FJI-Y9-ht is 361 cm3 g-1 () under 1 bar, corresponding to a BET surface area of 1117 m2 g-1, which is much lower than that (2061 m2 g-1) of FIR-29-ht under the same measurement conditions (Figure S3). The pore diameter distribution analysis by using density functional theory methods indicates a narrow pore size of 8.5 Å, which is according to the value estimated from the single-crystal structure and is smaller than the aperture diameter existing in FIR-29-ht (Figure S5). On the basis of the above sorption data, a micropore volume of 0.54 cm3 g-1 in FJI-Y9-ht is close to 0.49 cm3 g-1 estimated from the single-crystal structure and further confirms the structural stability of the host framework after heat activation.

Conclusion

In summary, by adjusting the arm length of two triphenylamine-based ligands (H3NTB and H3TCPA), we synthesized two nearly isostructural MOFs (FJI-Y9 and FIR-29) with honeycomb lattices of hexagonal channels. The consecutive slipped π⋅⋅⋅π-stacking interactions of the H3NTB and H3TCPA ligands on the surface of hexagonal channels make both MOFs stable for gas sorption. Compared to the reported FIR-29-ht with a BET surface area of 2061 m2 g-1 and a pore size of 16 Å, the activated FJI-Y9-ht shows an inferior BET surface area (1117 m2 g-1) and a narrow pore size (8.5 Å) but exhibits high H2 (202.3 cm3 g-1) and D2 (221.9 cm3 g-1) uptake under 77 K and 1 bar and C2H2 uptake of 168.9 cm3 g-1 under 273 K and 1 bar, which are all at least 48% enhancement over those of FIR-29-ht, indicating the vital importance of proper aperture in MOFs for H2, D2, and C2H2 storage.

metadata.title:
Optimizing H2, D2, and C2H2 Sorption Properties by Tuning the Pore Apertures in Metal–Organic
Frameworks
